etymologies: Old English cetel, cietel, of Germanic origin, based on Latin catillus, diminutive of catinus ‘deep container for cooking or serving food’. In Middle English the word's form was influenced by Old Norse ketill

definitions: a container or device in which water is boiled, having a lid, spout, and handle; a teakettle.
shortDefinitions: metal or plastic container with lid

definitions: a large metal pot for cooking, usually with a handle.
a bowl- or saucer-shaped container in which operations are carried out on metals or other substances with a low melting point.
shortDefinitions: container in which operations are carried out on metals with low melting point

definitions: a depression in the ground thought to have been formed by the melting of an ice block trapped in glacial deposits, especially one that is circular and deep

examples.text: our lake is probably a kettle

shortDefinitions: depression in ground thought to be formed by melting ice block

definitions: a small area in which demonstrators or protesters are confined by police seeking to maintain order during a demonstration

examples.text: activists in the kettle were protesting at being held and resisting arrest

shortDefinitions: area in which protesters are confined by police during demonstration

definitions: (of the police) confine (a group of demonstrators or protesters) to a small area, as a method of crowd control during a demonstration

examples.text: the plan was to get as close to the protest as possible without getting kettled

shortDefinitions: confine group of protesters to small area
